page.title: 12A Saxon church in Breamore 1
page.content: Breamore church, now dedicated to St. Mary, is an unusually complete example of late{Saxon architecture}of the 10th ,possibly 11th, century.The church is a large building(39.7m long) without aisles and of an embryonically cruciform structure,the tower occupying the centre of the cross, the chancel and nave the central beam, and two lateral chapels the arms. The North transept has vanished. The arch to the South transept bears in Anglo Saxon "But God hath in due time manifested to us the word".The three original corresponding arches probably completed the quotation but today only the letters DES survive. A Saxon rood over the entrance to the church within the North porch has been hideously mutilated.The figure of the Lord on the Cross and the hanging corpse of Judas can still be seen
